Ug. There are serious differences between external (submarine) pressure vessels and internal (propane tank) pressure vessels. It is not exactly the same. External pressure vessels are exposed to "crumpling" failure modes that internal pressure vessels aren't. Stiffness and rigidity become very important. This is not meant to disrespect the people who built the submarine, good for them, but they are right to limit it to shallow depths. But please, presenter, don't imply internal and external pressure vessels are the same!

Interesting thing about submarine escape hatches is that they learned to add a device to force them to stay open. When you try to escape at depth, the air in the sub comes out in bubbles because it has to be replaced with water. This causes the hatch to slam open and shut with enough force to cut a man in half- which is exactly what happened in the early days of submarines

Scuba Steve:

This video struck some inspiration in me. I'm currently designing a two man personal submarine very similar in shape to this one, but utilizing stiffening rings at two to three foot intervals which would increase the depth (rated by ASME standards for pressure vessels subject to external pressure) to roughly 305 ft. This makes my design depth of the submarine 200 ft for a 50% contingency. My current challenge is getting the combined assembly to weigh more than the bouyant force of the hull due to its displacement.
How did you guys overcome this challenge? I'm about to fill the hull volume with concrete to add on the weight.

My calculations for the volume of a 500 gal. propane tank (10ft length x 36" diameter) with 4x 5 gal. air banks means the hull has to weigh at least ~4500 lbs. to be neutrally bouyant.

I'd really appreciate being able to discuss some of the things you guys did for this project. I'm currently a nuke propulsion plant operator on a sub, and this is something I'm hell bent on doing. I just read your comment on the Optima Blue top AGM batteries, and find it funny that my design incorporates 4x Optima blue top batteries in a parallel bank supplying two Minn Kota motors (motor/prop housing filled with oil to prevent seawater entering/damaging seals due to diff. pressure at greater depths). That was independent of your choice, so it must be a decent route to go.

I would've first put it on a tether so it could be operated remotely for the first few dives to see if it could withstand the pressure and maintain trim. A propane tank is a little small unless you lie down in it, that's probably why they welded a bulge to it, weakening the structure.  Maybe a railcar tanker or underground water tank might be better, of course, welding internal reinforcement rings might be tricky without first splitting the structure in half and most underground water tanks are plastic so you couldn't weld those. A webcam on an extendable post could serve as a periscope.
